Inscription recording construction of a sphaeristrium by a father and son
Text fills the face, with traces of a larger line above; surviving line 1 is larger than the lines below.
Elegant tall and somewhat narrow v-cut letters with serifs. O is large, broad, and somewhat irregular in shape. R has curved and extended foot, P is open. G has straight foot.

Thirteen lines of Latin text, filling the available space.

Deeply engraved letters, somewhat irregular in height. A is consistently rendered without cross-bar. There is some fluidity between E, L, I and T, either one for the other, or simply rendered by a vertical stroke. Occasional use of ligatures. No interpunctuation.
First quarter of the 4th century CE (on the basis of the office of 'corrector')

The inscription is set out as five lines of large monumental Latin letters centred on the upper portion of the epigraphic field on the front face below the moulding (the field is 60W x 85 H). Lines 1 and 4 are larger.
Letters have standard serifs and a wide regular module; a variety of hedera and interpuncts are employed.
Terminus post quem of 195 CE, the deification of Commodus, and likely belongs to the reign of Septimius Severus

Honorific for Marcus Cestius, primus pilus and duumvir
Siciliae obiacentium insular et Bruttiorum antiquae tabulae cum animadversionibus Georgii Gualtheri
G. Gualtherus, Siciliae obiacentium insular et Bruttiorum antiquae tabulae cum animadversionibus Georgii Gualtheri (Panormi, 1624)
Gualtherus presents the text over four lines, the name filling line 1.
No details recorded, other than that Gualtherus marks a tall I in line 2 ('pilo').
Most likely to be one of the first generation of colonial settlers, and so probably Augustan in date, and (as Wilson 1990, p.369 n.58) unlikely to be later than Claudius.

Three lines of Latin letters, centred on the upper part of the front face of the base.

Deeply v-cut letters with minimal serifs and somewhat uneven in both height and width. Small triangular interpuncts throughout. C, O, G consistently large/wide. P is open, R is closed. E has equal bars.
Augustan; normally assumed to honour an original member of the colony, founded in 21 BCE by Augustus

Three lines of Latin text (despite abrasions, it is likely that there are no missing lines), seemingly set in the middle of the face of the base. Use of one triangular interpunct (line 2).
Text is very deeply and widely incised. Text is regular, with serifs. Spacing between letters and lines is precise.
Likely an early colonist of Thermae Himeraeae, probably Augustan in date (after 21 BCE).

Honours for an unknown member of the equestrian order
Line 1 is considerably larger than the others, while the spacing of line 5 suggests a clear effort to keep the text centered. The final line consists of widely spaced abbreviations.

Elegantly v-cut letters, with serifs and interpuncts and reasonably wide modules. Occasional tall letters (Y line 4, 55mm, I line 6, 48 mm) and some exuberant strokes, such as the Y in line 4 or the Q in line 5.

The post of governor of Cyprus precedes the transfer of the province to the Senate in 22 BCE, but only provides a terminus post quem for the inscription, which in any case must surely belong after the foundation of the colonia in 21 BCE, but not, therefore, by much.
Romano, 1829, Antiche iscrizioni inedite appartenenti alla città di Termini Imerese

Funerary inscription for Gaius Popillius Priscus

Eight lines of Latin text, in centre (but not centred) of stone. Use of triangular interpuncts, although some are faint and indistinct. Interpuncts are not used between every word. Line 1 is notably larger, line 2 reduces, the other lines much smaller.

Tall, elongated letters. Serifs used on many of the letters. First line is chiselled deeper into stone than subsequent ones. After line three, letter forms begin to lean to the left and become irregular.

The dating is contested by Bivona (later C1 CE, post-69) and Manganaro (a date shortly after 310-313 CE), based upon the reading of the word after 'Victoria' in line 4 (Bivona prefers Ticiniana, Manganaro Licininia). The other features of the text would seem to favour a later first rather than a fourth-century date.

Inscribed base of a dedication to Venus Victrix

A Latin text over 10 lines, engraved on the narrow front face
                                        of the base. The engraved face is 8 cm wide by 27.7 cm high.
                                        The majority of the words are run over onto the following
                                        line, with the final letters centred, suggesting that the
                                        visual effect was prioritised over the sense of the words.
                                        The text is large and well spaced in the upper part,
                                        becoming compressed towards the end, with the final lines
                                        overlapping.

Deeply, but rather irregularly cut letters.
                                    Y and T are tall, as is I in line 4; R is closed. Interpuncts in
                                    the form of a comma.
Korhonen suggests a date between the second half of the first and the end of the 2nd century CE
Photograph of front face by students of  Liceo M.M. Lazzaro

Dedication to the Genius of the city of Catania

The text is preserved intact, over seven lines, although the edge
                                        of the surviving stone clips the tops of the letters of the first line. The
                                        letters diminish in size over the first four lines, with a vacat in the second
                                        half of line four; the final three lines are larger again. The left margin of
                                        the text is maintained regularly, the right margin varies from line to line.

The letters are deeply but somewhat irregularly cut, with some
                                    internal variation (e.g. A appears with both broken and straight bar; E appears both
                                    as a tall narrow standard E and as a vertical stroke with a single horizontal bar
                                    across the middle; V appears both as V and as Y). Interpuncts are mostly absent,
                                    except after VC and CONS in the final two lines.

Munatidius is not otherwise known; the mention of three Domini
                                    requires one of the periods 337—340, 367—378, 379—383, 388—395, 402—408, and 421. A
                                    precise choice is not possible, but the consensus amongst scholars is for a date in
                                    the 4th century rather than later.
Photograph of front face by J. Prag

Letter of Iulius Paternus to the Emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus

Latin text preserved over 12 lines. The first line is in slightly larger and more widely spaced letters. The text closes up over lines 2 and 3, 
                                    with a more or less regular size and spacing over the rest of the stone. Interpuncts are used sparingly in the text, and their placing appears 
                                    deliberately intended to emphasise certain elements. The letters are neatly cut, with limited serifs (but sometimes substantial feet to vertical strokes), 
                                    and a tendency towards the taller narrower letters common from the second/third centuries AD onwards; this is particularly noticeable with 
                                    the letter E, which is not always easy to distinguish when corroded. Tall 'I' is employed. P is generally open.
164—166 CE, on basis of restoration of first word as Armeniacis when Aurelius and Verus both held this title
letter of iulius paternus to the emperors marcus aurelius and lucius verus

Inscribed statue base for Lucius Rubrius Proculus
Four lines of Latin text, centred on the stone and filling the face, slightly decreasing in size from line 1.

Large, plain, deeply cut letters. P is open, R and B are closed; some upright strokes (all letter I, some L and V) have a serif ascending upper right; plain interpuncts in lines 1 and 3; the numeral in line 3 is marked by a mid-bar.
Lettering and absence of filiation suggest a 2nd century CE date (Korhonen)

Bilingual sign advertising engraving of inscriptions

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.
Greek text includes lunate sigma and epsilon; extended apex to delta and alpha. Latin text is is regular with serifs, open P, closed R. There are no word dividers or punctuation in either text.

Augustan or Julio-Claudian,
                                by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian
                                parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE

Dedication to the Concordia of the Agrigentines
Seven lines of large Latin letters, centred on the stone. The planning of the text is uneven, with awkward word-breaks (lines 1-2 and 3-4, and some compression at line end, especially line 5

Tall, slightly curved letters, mostly with minimal serifs. P is open; R is closed with long tail; E has short horizontals of equal length, slightly upward curving; M is four equal slanting strokes. In line 5 the O and C of 'procos' are intelinked, and the following O is small and mid-line. A large diagonal upward stroke is visible above the first letter of each of the civic ethnics; and a horizontal above the Q at the end of line 6. The letters all show traces of dark paint (modern?).

Inscribed base of statue group of the Pii Fratres

Latin text preserved over six lines. Despite the extensive damage
                                        around the edges, almost all of the text appears to be preserved, with only a
                                        few letters lost from the right margin and at the top corners.

The letters show characteristic features of the more cursive style of
                                    late antiquity, with V having the large rounded U form.

The inscription cannot be later than the end of the 5th century,
                                    due to the archaeological evidence for the cessation of use of the theatre by that
                                    date

A single line of Hebrew is followed by 14 lines of Latin; the Latin text observes a more or less regular left margin, irregular on the right. The lower right and left corners contain small incised menorahs, with the last line of text between them consisting simply of 'overspill' from the preceding line, offset towards the right.

Letters generally neatly and regularly cut, with basic serifs on the long strokes. B is somewhat irregular in fomration, sometimes with equal loops, sometimes with smaller upper loop; C is large and open; E is narrow, with three short equal horizontal strokes; G has distinctive form of small C with a tail descending to lower right; M is formed of four equal diagonal strokes; P has a somewhat elongated frequently (but not always) closed loop, but some instances have a wide horizaontal foot also; Q is closed with a trailing tail;  R is usually closed, with a tail usually straight and extended but finishing above the line; S is frequently oversize. The two menorahs at the foot of the inscription are 15 mm and 23 mm (the left is incomplete).
Photo by students of Liceo Lazzaro, 2017-05-11

A single line of deep cut very regular Greek letters with some traces of stucco preserved within the letters (and elsewhere on the stone)

Regular letters, deep cut without serifs. Epsilon has equal length bars; P has equal vertical strokes and no overhang on the horizontal; omega is closed (some variation on the position of the horizontal) and slightly smaller than the other letters; alpha has straight bar. There is a circular interpunct and space before the final letter.

Seven lines of Greek letters, filling the face, with a regular left margin, the final line approximately centred; the text is engraved by means of individual dots punched with a rounded tool.

Regular neatly cut letters, with pronounced terminations to the strokes. Alpha has broken bar; beta a much smaller upper eye, just closed; epsilon has nearly equal strokes; zeta formed by vertical with horizontal top and bottom; kappa has shortened arms; mu has midstrokes descending only half-way, curved rather than angular, and not always reaching the top of the verticals; xsi formed by three horizontals only, the middle one shorter; omicron is full size; pi has horizontal extending beyond the verticals; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is standard height, with ovoid eye; omega is closed, and tear-drop shaped.
Later second or earlier first century BCE

Apollonia(?) honours Andron son of Thrasios
Four lines of Greek text, not quite centred, but lines 2 and 3 fill the width of the face.

Plain cut letters without serifs, of Hellenistic form. Alpha is straight bar (except possibly  broken bar in line 1); beta has two small closed eyes, with a gap between; epsilon has shorter middle bar; the form of theta is unclear (small circle or cross at centre?); kappa has small arms opening from the mid-point of the vertical; mu has curving middle strokes which reach down to the line, but vertical first and last; omicron is generally slightly smaller than the other letters; pi has equal length strokes without overlap; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omega is closed and very slightly elongated, slightly smaller than other letters.
Photo J.Prag courtesy Soprintendenza BBCCAA di Messina

The municipium of the Haluntini honours Gnaeus Pollienus
The text occupies five lines over the upper part of the front face.

Regular letters with a fairly square module, simply engraved without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; Kappa has full length arms; Mu has vertical first and last, with mid-strokes only descending half-way; omicron is full size; Pi has full length verticals, and slightly overlapping horizontal bar; omega is slightly open and nearly circular, with horizontal tails/feet.

The use of the term 'municipium' in Greek places this text almost certainly after the grant of Latin rights to Sicily by Julius Caesar (probably 46 BCE), but equally the use of Greek implies a date not later than the early Augustan period. The lettering is compatible with a late Hellenistic date.

six lines of Greek letters in a recessed field 23 cm high, with consistent left margin, uneven right margin, at times rather compressed on the right (e.g. line 5), and vacat below.

Neat and regular letters without serfis (but slight terminal marks to the strokes). Alpha with straight cross bar, beta with equal closed eyes, epsilon with short middle stroke, theta slightly ovoid with detached middle bar, kappa with short arms, mu with almost vertical first and last, and three-quarter mid-strokes; xsi with three horizontal bars, lowest the longest; omicron smaller and mid-line, pi with equal vertical strokes; rho rounded closed eye; sigma with very slightly open top and bottom strokes; phi with round eye, slightly extended vertical; omega mostly circular, slightly open, short horizontal feet.
3rd or 2nd century BCE, lettering of the early-mid Hellenistic.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 22-03-2017

1ἀμφὶ παραστάσι ταῖσδε Σαράπιδος Ἑστίαι ἁγνὸν
2βωμὸν Βαρκαῖος Καρνεάδης ἔθετο
3Εὐκρίτου υἱός ξεῖνε ὁ νεωκόρος ἅ θ’ ὁμόλεκτρο[ς]
4Πυθιὰς ἁ κείνου καὶ θυγάτηρ Ἐρασώ
5ἀνθ’ ὧν ὦ κραίνουσα Διὸς μεγαλαυχέας οἴκους
6θυμαρὴν βιοτᾶς ὄλβον ἔχοιεν ἀεί.
Lines 1, 4 and 7 are set further to the left, with the other lines indented by one character space, reflecting the beginning of each line of hexameter verse.
Regular letters: lunate Ε, Σ, cursive Ω, Α with broken bar.
Late 3rd — late 4th century CE (Korhonen on the basis of lettering)

1Ε[ἰς Κ]αίσαρα Αὔγουστον φλάμενος Λουκίου Ἐγνατίου [Λ]ου̣[κί]ου υἱοῦ Γαλ̣(ερίᾳ)[---]
2(vac.)[---]δυῶν δὲ ἀ[νδ]ρῶν
3Σέξτου Ἐ[να]τ̣ί̣ου̣ Σ[έ]ξ[τ]ο[υ υἱοῦ Ῥ]ούφου
4Λούκιος [. 5.]ς Λουκίου υἱὸ[ς..]ο[---γυμνασίαρχος τῶν τε ἐφήβων καὶ νε]ωτέρων τοὺς ἀν[κ]λίτας ἐκ τῶν ἰδίων Ἑρμᾶι καὶ Ἡρακλε[ῖ]

Regular and neat letters without serifs. Alpha with both straight and broken bar, beta with closed loops (upper slightly smaller), Mu has full length slanting strokes; omicron full size; sigma has horizontal top and bottom; rhomboid omega.

2nd or 1st century BCE (as late as early Augustan acc. to Wilson and Manni Piraino; but Manni Piraino also suggests 2nd century BCE). The form of the letters surely suggests an earlier date in this range.
Manni Piraino, 1963, Due Iscrizioni inedite di Marsala

1T(ito) · Flavio Ionio

Greek text over four lines, centred in the main panel of the
                                        tabula ansata on the front face of the urn.

Neat and regular square letters. Phi and omicron are rhomboid in
                                    form; standard four-bar sigma; epsilon has horizontal bars of equal length; alpha
                                    has a slightly extended apex; mu has extended apices, and all four strokes are full
                                    length and off-vertical. There is one instance of ligature in line 3, and
                                    interpuncts are in the form of simple triangular incisions.
69 CE — first half of 2nd century CE
